justification: The paper describes the clicking task as a physical effort task used to measure people's risk preferences for effort. Participants had to click on a black response circle presented at randomly selected locations on the screen. The task was designed to study the interaction between probability and magnitude of effort changes.

The adding task is described as a cognitive effort task that measures risk preferences for effort. Participants had to select two numbers from a grid that summed to 10, requiring mental effort. The task was used alongside the clicking task to generate data for comparison.

This control experiment used monetary gallbles to measure risk preferences and establish a baseline comparison against the effort-based tasks. Participants chose between options for different amounts of money to ensure that the results of the effort tasks were analyzed in a comparable manner.
